{{Infobox musical artist | name = Holly Thee Maxwell | image = File:Holle Thee Maxwell.jpg | caption = Holle Thee Maxwell at the Lincoln Center | alias = Holly Maxx; Holly Maxwell; Holle Maxwell;Holle Thee Maxwell; The Original Black Blonde Bombshell | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Holly Thee MarClaRoDe' Maxwell | birth_date = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1945|10|17}} | birth_place = [[Chicago, Illinois]], [[United States]] | instrument = Vocals | genre = [[Opera]], [[jazz]], [[soul music|soul]], [[blues]], [[R&B]], [[Pop music|pop]], [[country music|country]] | occupation = Vocalist, songwriter | years_active = 1950–present | label = | associated_acts = [[Ike Turner]], [[Jimmy Smith (musician)|Jimmy Smith]], [[The Temptations]], [[The Impressions]], [[Little Johnny Taylor|Johnny Taylor]], [[The Spinners (American R&B group)|The Spinners]], [[The Dells]], [[Captain & Tennille]], Fred Williamson, and Reynaldo Rey | website = | notable_instruments = }} '''Holle Thee Maxwell''' (born October 17, 1945) is an American vocalist and songwriter known for her versatile performance abilities and command of a wide range of genres including [[opera]], [[jazz]], [[soul music|soul]], [[blues]], [[R&B]], [[Pop music|pop]], and [[country music|country]]. She performed with soul and blues artist [[Ike Turner]] and jazz organist [[Jimmy Smith (musician)|Jimmy Smith]]. [[Bobby Blue Bland|Bobby Bland]] used one of the songs she wrote in his critically acclaimed album, "Come Fly with Me". Her six decade career spans opera training in childhood, a soul balladeer in the 1960s, extensive European tours, and performances in the [[Chicago Blues Festival]]. The [[Midem|Cannes Musical Festival]] named her "Queen of Entertaining Entertainers". ==Life and career== Maxwell first sang professionally at the age of five. She studied classical voice and piano from age nine to seventeen.{{cite book|last=Pruter|first=Robert|title=Chicago Soul |year=1991|publisher=University of Illinois Press|location=Urbana and Chicago|isbn=978-0-252-06259-9|pages=67–69; 205–6}} At age twelve, she was featured at the Chicago [[Civic Opera House (Chicago)|Civic Opera House]].{{cite journal |last1=Porter|first1=James|year=2005|title=C'est la vie, Holle: She's big in France, but blues trooper Holle Thee Maxwell can't buy a break in her hometown.|journal=[[Time Out Chicago|Time Out Magazine]]|publisher=Time Out Digital Ltd.|url=http://www.timeoutchicago.com/music-nightlife/music/45236/cest-la-vie-holle|accessdate=August 5, 2013}} Maxwell holds two degrees in music from the Chicago Musical College of [[Roosevelt University]] and [[The Juilliard School]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ultimateunderground.com/upcoming-shows/the-underground-experience-presents-the-power-of-black-music-culture-sessions-series-6-featuring-holle-thee-maxewell-mr-charles-reese|title=THE Underground Experience Presents "The Power Of Black Music & Culture Sessions" Series # 6″ Featuring Holle Thee Maxwell & Mr. Charles Reese! |author= |date= |website=ultimateunderground.com|publisher=Ultimate Underground|accessdate=July 31, 2013}} Even though her mother had her attend modeling and finishing school and classical musical training, Maxwell discovered soul late in high school. She said, "Around the age of seventeen, I started sneaking around off to the nightclubs and looking at [[Harold Burrage]], [[Otis Clay]], [[Johnny Williams (blues musician)|Little Johnny Williams]]. I used to watch these artists because they had so much soul, so much whatever." She briefly sang with a [[girl group]] called the Tourjourettes while attending [[Paul Robeson High School (Chicago)|Parker High School]] in Chicago. Bunky Sheppard discovered Maxwell in early 1965 and produced her first singles for [[Ewart Abner|Constellation Records]], starting with "One Thin Dime" that had good play in Chicago. In the summer of 1965, Maxwell was featured in Beatrice Watson's column in the ''[[Chicago Defender]]''. Chicago Soul historian Robert Pruter wrote the following about Watson's report:
...Holly's mother, Eula Maxwell, took pains to assure the ''Defender'' reporter that her daughter was still progressing toward becoming an opera singer. Holly herself pointed out that she had been singing jazz for two and a half years and was singing r&b as a step up.
Star Records produced Maxwell's single "Philly Barracuda" in 1966 complete with instructions on how to perform the "Philly Dog" dance. Star promoted the record with an appearance of deejay Herb Kent at the [[Crane High School (Chicago)|Crane High School]] with Maxwell getting up on the table to sing the song while demonstrating how to do the dance. Maxwell reached a crossroads in her career when she made the mistake in 1967 of singing the pop song, "[[Misty (song)|Misty]]", while performing at a former R&B Chicago nightclub called Peyton Place on the same bill as Hi-Fi White, a blues vocalist and transvestite comedian known for lewd jokes. When she ran crying to dressing room after the audience threw oranges and beer bottles at her for her performance, Hi Fi White told her, "Honey, you ain't got no soul." She was determined "to get this soul". She listened to [[Gladys Knight]] and [[Aretha Franklin]] and practiced singing for four months until she taught herself to sing soul at the age of twenty-two. She returned to the Peyton Place and bedazzled the audience with a "devastating" rendition of "[[Respect (song)|Respect]]". Maxwell had solo gigs in Chicago clubs and occasionally sang as backup for [[Barbara Acklin]].{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/holly-maxwell-mn0001362688/biography|title=Holly Maxwell Biography|last1=Hamilton|first1=Andrew |website=allmusic.com|publisher=All Media Network, LLC.|accessdate=August 29, 2013}} Maxwell recorded singles for the record labels [[Curtom Records]], Smit Whit Records, and Star Records in the 1960s and 1970s. She had regional hits across the United States with the songs "Only When Your Lonely", "One Thin Dime", "Never Love Again", "Suffer", and "Philly Barracuda".{{cite web |url=http://www.chicagobluesguide.com/features/holle-thee-maxwell-interview/holle-thee-maxwell-page.html|title=Chicago Blues/R&B diva to bring her feisty style to Chicago Blues Fest and beyond|last1=Schelkopf|first1=Eric|website= chicagobluesguide.com |publisher= Chicago Blues Guide LLC accessdate=August 5, 2013}} Collectors worldwide seek her singles, especially [[Northern Soul]] enthusiasts in Europe. Maxwell moved to California for most of the 1970s and early 1980s. During this time Maxwell owned a nightclub and sang for two years with jazz organist Jimmy Smith. Maxwell replaced [[Tina Turner]] in Ike Turner's band from 1977 to 1985 mostly in Europe.{{cite news |title=Holly Maxx credits Ike Turner with putting her head straight |first=Ian|last=Gillespie|url=http://www.lfpress.com|newspaper=[[The London Free Press]]|date=July 22, 1993|accessdate= August 2, 2013}} She performed with Ike Turner again for eight months in 1992. Despite the controversy surrounding Tina Turner's separation from Ike Turner, Maxwell reported a positive working partnership with him. Maxwell returned to Chicago in 1985. French club owner Gérard Vacher saw Maxwell perform at the [[Kingston Mines]] in 1996 and booked her at his club, Quai du Blues or the Maxwell Café Supper Club. Maxwell became co-owner of this club known in France as "the home of real American blues."{{cite news|title=Singing diva Holly Thee Maxwell returns triumphantly from Paris|author=Staff|url=http://highbeam.com/doc/1P3-540636971.html|newspaper=Chicago Defender|date=October 2, 2003|accessdate=September 22, 2013}} In 2005 she remained a hit in France.{{cite web |url=http://www.quaidublues.com/resumesuk.htm|title=Unforgettable Evening with the Legends of Afro-American Music |author= |date= |website=quaidublues.com|accessdate=August 8, 2013}} She was a regular performer at Maxwell Café in [[Paris]] and nightclubs in [[London]] and Europe. She was named "Queen of Entertaining Entertainers" by the Cannes Musical Festival.{{cite web|url=http://chicagobluesmamas.com/chicago-blues-mamas-apap-nyc/ |title=What’s the Blues Got to Do with it? Everything! Chicago's Red Hot Blues Royalty in New York City to Salute Women of The Blues Starring Holle Thee Maxwell & Nelle Tiger Travis of Chicago Blues Mamas|author=|website=chicagoblues mamas.com|publisher=Chicago Blues Mamas |accessdate=August 9, 2013}} Maxwell joined Chicago Women in Blues at Reggie's Rock Club in Chicago in 2011 in response to the Chicago Blues Festival lineup of almost all male performers.{{cite news|title=Chicago Women in Blues set for Evanston gig at SPACE|first=J.T.|last= Morand|url=http://www.suntimes.com/entertainment/music/14163082-421/story.html|newspaper=[[Chicago Sun Times]]|date=August 1, 2012|accessdate=August 2, 2013}} She hosted an all-female performance at the 2011 Chicago Blues Festival that featured Liz Mandeville, Demetria Taylor, Peaches Staten, and Ramblin' Rose.{{cite news|title=The ''Reader's'' Guide to the Chicago Blues Festival|first1=David|last1=Whiteis |first2=Bill|last2=Dahl|first3=Peter|last3= Margasak |url=http://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/chicago-blues-fest-guide-2011/Content?oid=4026945 |newspaper=[[Chicago Reader]]|date= June 9, 2011 |accessdate=August 2, 2013}} In January 2014, the Great Black Music Project of the [[Northeastern Illinois University]] honored Maxwell by adding her to their artist registry and podcasting their interview of her about her music career.{{cite web|url=http://chicagobluesmamas.com/chicago-blues-mamas-apap-nyc/ |title=What’s the Blues Got to Do with it? Everything! Chicago's Red Hot Blues Royalty in New York City to Salute Women of The Blues Starring Holle Thee Maxwell & Nelle Tiger Travis of Chicago Blues Mamas|author=|website=http://greatblackmusicproject.org/en/artists/new-podcast-hollee-maxwell-blonde-bombshell-0|publisher=The Great Black Music Project |accessdate=February 13, 2014}} Maxwell has never stopped working in her six decade career{{cite web|url=http://www.wciu.com/youandme.php?assetID=10005831 |title=Holle Thee Maxwell Web Extra|author=|date=June 9, 2011|website=wciu.com|publisher=WCIU-TV Limited Partnership|accessdate=August 9, 2013}} that spans opera training in childhood, a soul balladeer in the 1960s, and extensive European tours {{cite news|title=More fest high points|author= |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2013-05-30/entertainment/ct-ott-0531-blues-festival-side-20130530_1_quinn-sullivan-chicago-blues-festival-crossroads-stage|newspaper= Chicago Tribune|date=May 20, 2013|accessdate=2 August 2013}} to currently performing in varied settings that include Chicago clubs, the Chicago Blues Festival, and hosting a musical/historical tour of Chicago's soul and blues with [[Jimmy Burns]].{{cite web|url=http://chicagosoulbluesbus.eventbrite.com/|title=Soul Tour of Chicago|author=|date= June 10, 2013|website=|publisher=Eventbrite |accessdate=August 5, 2013}} On June 8, 2014, Maxwell will be inducted into the Chicago Blues Hall of Fame at [[Buddy Guy's Legends]].{{cite web|url=http://www.blueshalloffame.com/Local_Blues_Talent/Local_Blues_Talent_of_Chicago_Illinois_2014.html|title=Chicago Blues Hall of Fall 2014 Inductees|author=|year=2014|website=BluesHallofFame.org|publisher=Chicago Blues of Hall Fame|accessdate=May 23, 2014}} ==Music and Performance Style== Maxwell sings wide-ranging genres of opera, soul, jazz, rock, country, and blues. She sings in multiple languages of English, French, German, and Italian. ''American Blues News'' reported that her early influences included [[Shirley Temple]], [[Mae West]], [[Marian Anderson]], [[Josephine Baker]], and [[Dinah Shore]]."{{cite web|url=http://www.ameriblues.com/2009/10/07/chicago-blues-holle-thee-maxwell-is-thee-original-black-blonde-bombshell/|title=Holle Thee Maxwell is The Original Black Bombshell|author=|date=October 7, 2009|website= ameriblues.com|publisher=American Blues News|accessdate=August 5, 2013}} Blues great Bobby Bland affirmed her songwriting skill when he used one of her songs in his critically acclaimed album, "Come Fly with Me".{{cite web|url=http://www.kjazzradiouk.com/2011/09/01/hollethee-maxwell/|title=Diva singer Holle Thee Maxwell|author=|website=kjazzradiouk.com|publisher=KJazz Radio UK|accessdate=August 9, 2013}} In 1978, South African reviewer Roy Christie credited the success of the [[Jimmy Smith]] show to "the electrifying performance of Holly Maxwell." He wrote, "She is virtually a reincarnation of Billie ([[Billie Holiday]])."{{cite news|title= Holly is reincarnation of Billie, Ell et al|first=Roy|last=Christie|url= http://www.thestar.co.za |newspaper=[[The Star (South Africa)|The Star]]|date= December 5, 1978|accessdate=August 2, 2013}} Reviewer Aaron Cohen in more recent years described Maxwell as rendering Billie Holiday's "[[God Bless the Child (Billie Holiday song)|God Bless the Child]]" with "outright defiance."{{cite web |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2013-06-10/entertainment/ct-ent-0611-blues-fest-wrap-20130610_1_chicago-blues-festival-demetria-taylor-james-cotton|title=Chicago showed off its chops at a rollicking Blues Fest|last=Cohen|first=Aaron|date=June 10, 2013|website= chicagotribune.com|publisher=Tribune Newspaper|accessdate=July 31, 2013}} However, other observers report that Maxwell's rendition of "God Bless the Child" moves people to cry or cheer. American Blues News reviewer commented that Maxwell has versatile performance abilities. He wrote, "When she picks up a mike, the cord is a fuse, because she explodes on stage... She can be quite bawdy at times and her audiences love it, including me!" Blues critic David Whiteis noted in 2009 that Maxwell's performance style evolved from a "sweet voiced 'girl singer' who melted hearts back in the day" to "a growling, provocatively clad sex kitten."{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/the-readers-guide-to-chicago-blues-fest-2009/Content?oid=1123041|title=The Reader's Guide to Chicago Blues Fest 2009|last1=Whiteis|first1=David|last2=Dahl|first2=Bill|date=June 11, 2009|website=chicagoreader.org|publisher= un-Times Media, LLC|accessdate=August 7, 2013}} ==Discography== ===Singles=== *''(Happiness Will Cost You) One Thin Dime / It's Impossible'' (1965) - Constellation Records{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/artist/Holly+Maxwell|title=Hollee Thee|author= |date= |website=Discogs|publisher=|accessdate=July 31, 2013}} *''Philly Barracuda Part 1'' (1966) - Star{{cite web |url= http://www.soulfulkindamusic.net/hmaxwell.htm |title= Holly Maxwell |author= |date= |website= soulfulkindamusic.net |publisher= Soulful Kinda Music Website & Magazine |accessdate=7 August 2013}} *''Philly Barracuda Part 2'' (1966) - Star *''Don't Say You Love Me Until You Do / Blueberry Hill'' (1966) - Star *''Heartbeat / It Was A Very Good Year'' (1967) - [[Checker Records]] *''Suffer'' with [[The Impressions]] as backup vocals(1969) - Curtom Records *''Never Love Again / Winter Go Away'' (3 versions) (1970) - Smit-Whit Records *''Only When You're Lonely / Let Him Go For Himself'' (2010 Promo) - Constellation Records *''Only When You're Single'' (2012) - Holle Thee Maxwell{{cite web |url=http://www.emusic.com/browse/album/all/label:761777/?sort=downloads |title=Holle Thee Maxwell/Tunecore|author= |date= |website=emusic.com|publisher= |accessdate=July 31, 2013}} ===Albums=== *''Holle Thee Maxwell...Thee Blonde Bombshell'' (1972) - Unknown record label *''Jimmy Smith Plays for the People'' (1978) - Jimmy Smith performs with H.
